Message.Issue: 'frmMain.frmMain(bool)' calls into 'SystemEvents.DisplaySettingsChanged.add(EventHandler)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'SystemEvents.DisplaySettingsChanged.add(EventHandler)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'frmMain.frmMain(bool)' ->'frmMain.frmMain(bool)'

'frmMain.frmMain(bool)' calls into 'SystemEvents.UserPreferenceChanging.add(UserPreferenceChangingEventHandler)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'SystemEvents.UserPreferenceChanging.add(UserPreferenceChangingEventHandler)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'frmMain.frmMain(bool)' ->'frmMain.frmMain(bool)'
'frmMain' contains field 'frmMain.currentProfile' that is of IDisposable type: 'Profile'. Change the Dispose method on 'frmMain' to call Dispose or Close on this field.

'Hotkey.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)' calls into 'Message.Msg.get()' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'Message.Msg.get()' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'Hotkey.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)' ->'Hotkey.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)'

'Hotkey.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)' calls into 'Message.WParam.get()' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'Message.WParam.get()' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'Hotkey.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)' ->'Hotkey.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)'

Add the following security attribute to 'Hotkey.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)' in order to match a LinkDemand on base method 'IMessageFilter.PreFilterMessage(ref Message)': [SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.LinkDemand, Flags = SecurityPermissionFlag.UnmanagedCode)].

'Hotkey.Register(Control)' calls into 'Marshal.GetLastWin32Error()' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'Marshal.GetLastWin32Error()' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'Hotkey.Register(Control)' ->'Hotkey.Register(Control)'
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Hotkey.RegisterHotKey(IntPtr, int, uint, Keys)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Hotkey.UnregisterHotKey(IntPtr, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on 'Profile' or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.
Modify 'Profile.Dispose()' so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.
Make 'Settings.MainHandle' private.

Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on 'Zone' or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.AttachThreadInput(uint, uint, bool)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.BringWindowToTop(IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Modify 'Zone.Dispose()' so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.GetClassName(IntPtr, StringBuilder, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'lpClassName' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.GetCurrentThreadId()' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.GetForegroundWindow()' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.GetWindowThreadProcessId(IntPtr, IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.SetWindowPos(IntPtr, IntPtr, int, int, int, int, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Zone.ShowWindow(IntPtr, uint)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Implement IDisposable on 'ZoneTemplate' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'Bitmap'. If 'ZoneTemplate' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

Rule.Name: Avoid uncalled private code
Rule.Description: There is uncalled code that is not externally visible and is not a known runtime entry point. If this violation fires in error, please send a problem report to the Visual Studio Code Analysis team.

Rule.Name: Disposable fields should be disposed
Rule.Description: If a type that implements IDisposable owns fields that also implement IDisposable, the encapsulating type's Dispose() implementation should call Dispose() on each disposable field.
Rule.Resolution: {0} contains field {1} that is of IDisposable type: {2}. Change the Dispose method on {0} to call Dispose or Close on this field.

Rule.Name: Do not indirectly expose methods with link demands
Rule.Description: Do not wrap a method protected by a LinkDemand with a method that does not perform a security check. A LinkDemand checks the permissions of the immediate caller rather than checking the permissions of all callers in the call stack. In this case, the permissions of the wrapper method will be checked. If the wrapper method does not, itself, check the permissions of callers higher in the call stack, malicious code might be able to execute the wrapped function even though it lacks permission to do so.
Rule.Resolution: {0} calls into {1} which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, {1} is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: {2}

Rule.Name: Implement IDisposable correctly
Rule.Description: All IDisposable types should implement the Dispose pattern correctly.
Rule.Resolution: Modify {0} so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.

Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on {0} or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.

Rule.Name: Move P/Invokes to NativeMethods class
Rule.Description: This type contains members with the DllImport attribute. Members with the DllImport attribute should be contained in classes named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Rule.Resolution: Because it is a P/Invoke method, {0} should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Rule.Name: Override link demands should be identical to base
Rule.Description: If a virtual method has a LinkDemand, in many cases, so should any override of it, and if an override has a LinkDemand, so should the overridden virtual method. Because it is possible to call any of the overrides of a virtual method explicitly, they should all have the same LinkDemand status or, if not, should be reviewed. This also applies to LinkDemand security checks for methods that part of an interface implementation, because the caller might use an interface-typed reference to access the method.
Rule.Resolution: Add the following security attribute to {0} in order to match a LinkDemand on base method {1}: {2}.

Rule.Name: Pointers should not be visible
Rule.Description: IntPtr and UIntPtr fields should be declared as private. Exposing non-private pointers can cause a security weakness.

Rule.Name: Specify marshaling for P/Invoke string arguments
Rule.Description: When marshaling strings as ANSI (or as Auto on Win9x), some characters may be changed. If best-fit mapping is on, strings that appear different in Unicode will be marshaled to identical ANSI strings, which may lead to incorrect security decisions. Turning best-fit mapping off reduces this risk, as all characters without equivalents are mapped to '?'. Also, note that CharSet.Ansi is the default setting for all string marshaling; Unicode marshaling must be specified explicitly, either as a CharSet setting of DllImport or StructLayout, or as a MarshalAs attribute with a Unicode (or system-dependent) UnmanagedType.
Rule.Resolution: To reduce security risk, marshal parameter {0} as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.

Rule.Name: Types that own disposable fields should be disposable
Rule.Description: Types that declare disposable members should also implement IDisposable. If the type does not own any unmanaged resources, do not implement a finalizer on it.
Rule.Resolution: Implement IDisposable on {0} because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: {1}. If {0} has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.
